[[Monza]], [[Italy]] | Course = Permanent racing facility | Course_mi = 3.600 | Course_km = 5.793 | Distance_laps = 53 | Distance_mi = 190.587 | Distance_km = 306.720 | Weather = | Attendance = | Pole_Driver = [[Kimi Räikkönen]] | Pole_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] | Pole_Time = 1:19.119 | Pole_Country = FIN | Fast_Driver = {{Flagicon|GBR}} [[Lewis Hamilton]] | Fast_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] | Fast_Time = 1:22.497 | Fast_Lap = 30 | First_Driver = [[Lewis Hamilton]] | First_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] | First_Country = GBR | Second_Driver = [[Kimi Räikkönen]] | Second_Team = [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] | Second_Country = FIN | Third_Driver = [[Valtteri Bottas]] | Third_Team = [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] | Third_Country = FIN | Lapchart = {{F1Laps2018|ITA}} }} The '''2018 Italian Grand Prix''' (formally the '''Formula 1 Gran Premio Heineken d'Italia 2018''') was a [[Formula One racing|Formula One motor race]] held on 2 September 2018 at the [[Autodromo Nazionale Monza]] in [[Monza|Monza, Italy]]. The race was the fourteenth round of the [[2018 Formula One World Championship]] and marked the 88th running of the [[Italian Grand Prix]] and the 83rd time the race was held at Monza. [[Mercedes-Benz in Formula One|Mercedes]] driver [[Lewis Hamilton]] entered the round with a 17-point lead over [[Sebastian Vettel]] in the Drivers' Championship. In the World Constructors' Championship, Mercedes led [[Scuderia Ferrari|Ferrari]] by 15 points. ==Classification== ===Qualifying=== {|class=wikitable style="font-size:85%" !rowspan=2|{{Tooltip|Pos.|Qualifying position}} !rowspan=2|{{Tooltip|Car

revision.text:
{{lead rewrite|date=March 2017}} [[File:Air Jordan XII Playoffs.jpg|thumb|Air Jordan XII Playoffs]]
[[Michael Jordan]], one of the [[NBA]]'s most iconic basketball player, has his own shoe line with the brand [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]]. His logo is a silhouette of him jumping, also known as the [[Jumpman (logo)|Jumpman]]. He is one of many Hall of Fame members and is recognized as one of the greatest to play the game of basketball. Many refer to this shoe as the "Flu Game" because of the statistics that Michael Jordan had. He was playing the [[Utah Jazz]] for the [[NBA]] Finals where he played in the Jordan 12 and with the flu. Since that game, this shoe has become increasingly popular, therefore [[Air Jordan]] released more colors but limiting the amount that they produce.
They were not only liked and worn by Jordan himself but also by some of his teammates, which included [[Scottie Pippen]], [[Bill Wennington]] and [[Luc Longley]]. Scottie Pippen even fell out of the MaxAir System to have his player edition of the Air Jordan 12. <ref>{{cite web|title=The Complete History of the Air Jordans I – XX8Air Jordan XII|url=http://www.complex.com/sneakers/2013/07/air-jordan-complete-history-from-i-xx8/air-jordan-xii|website=Complex|language=en}}</ref>
== Creation and Release== The Air Jordan 12 took the Air Jordan series to a new height. It got its inspiration from two sources: [[Nisshoki]] (The Japanese flag) and a women’s shoe-design from the 19th century. The stitching along the side of the shoe resembles sun rays which were borrowed from the Japanese Sun Rising Flag and placed on the Air Jordan 12. Michael Jordan wanted the shoe both comfortable and durable, and didn't bother if they took something from women’s shoes.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Complete History of the Nike Air Jordan 12 Sneaker|url=https://www.lacesout.net/resources/history-of-jordan-sneaker/jordan-12/|website=www.lacesout.net}}</ref>
The Air Jordan XII was originally released from 1996-1997, when the [[Chicago Bulls]] were trying to win another championship for the second time in a row. Five colorways were released for the shoe and they were the first Air Jordan to feature Zoom Air. <ref>{{cite web|title=Air Jordan 12: The Definitive Guide to Colorways|url=https://solecollector.com/news/air-jordan-12-the-definitive-guide-to-colorways/|website=Sole Collector|language=en}}</ref> They were originally released from 1996 to 1997 and was retro-ed in 2003, 2004, 2008, 2009, 2011–2013, and 2015–2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/playerfile/ray_allen/ |title=Ray Allen Stats, Bio and Game Logs |publisher=NBA.com |date=1975-07-20 |accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref>
==Price== The Air Jordan 12 has been subject to many highly limited colorways recently such as the ''Air Jordan 12 x PSNY'' collaboration, the ''Wings'' colorway that was limited to 12,000 pairs, and the ''OVO'' collaboration. Due to limited pairs, the Jordan 12's vary in price from {{dollarsign|USD|190|lk=on}}–{{dollarsign|USD|225|lk=off}}. ==References== {{reflist}}

{{National football association | Logo = Antigua & Barbuda Football Association 2.jpg | Badge_size = 200px | Founded = 1928 | FIFA affiliation = 1970 | Region = [[CONCACAF]] | Region affiliation = between 1961 and 1973CONCACAF was founded in 1961. {{cite web|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/jm/kingston/kingston/kingston-gleaner/1973/02-13/page-14|title=Abrahams likely to head CONCACAF|date=13 February 1973|publisher=[[Kingston Gleaner]] in newspaperarchive.com|accessdate= }}
"The Caribbean CONCACAF members are Jamaica, Antigua, Bahamas, Barbados, Cuba, Haiti, Netherland Antilles, Puerto Rico, Surinam, Trinidad and the Dominican Republic." | President = Everton Gonsalves | Coach = [[Derrick Edwards]] | }} The '''Antigua and Barbuda Football Association''' is the governing body of football in [[Antigua and Barbuda]].http://www.antiguaobserver.com/abfa-improving-coaching-skills/ They control the [[Antigua and Barbuda national football team]]. ==Competitions== The ABFA oversees the administration of [[Antigua and Barbuda]]'s football leagues; the [[Antigua and Barbuda Premier Division|Premier Division]], [[Antigua and Barbuda First Division|First Division]], [[Antigua and Barbuda Second Division|Second Division]] and the [[Antigua and Barbuda Female Division|Female Division]] as well as the [[Antigua and Barbuda FA Cup]]. ==National Stadium== The ABFA's official national stadium is the [[Antigua Recreation Ground]] which have recently been approved to host World Cup 2010 qualifying matches. An attempt to have the [[Sir Vivian Richards Stadium]] approved for matches was rebuffed due to "ongoing works."{{Cite web |url=http://www.footballantigua.com/news_details.php?subaction=showfull&id=1202217485&archive=&start_from=&ucat=2& |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920062215/http://www.footballantigua.com/news_details.php?subaction=showfull&id=1202217485&archive=&start_from=&ucat=2& |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-09-20 |title=FIFA Approves the ARG |accessdate=2008-07-06 |publisher=ABFA }} ==External links== * [http://www.antiguafootball.com/ ABFA] - Official Site * [https://www.fifa.com/associations/association=atg/index.html Antigua and Barbuda] at the FIFA website. * [http://www.concacaf.com/team/antigua-barbuda Antigua and Barbuda] at CONCACAF site ==References== {{reflist}} {{Sports governing bodies in Antigua and Barbuda}} {{Football in Antigua and Barbuda}} {{CONCACAF associations}} {{International football}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Antigua And Barbuda Football Association}} [[Category:CONCACAF member associations]] [[Category:Football in Antigua and Barbuda]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Antigua and Barbuda]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Antigua and Barbuda]] {{Antigua-sport-stub}} {{footy-org-stub}}

They play in the Beninese first division, the [[Benin Premier League]].[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/benin/association-sportive-oussou-saka/20791/] ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 35,000 capacity [[Stade Charles de Gaulle]]. ==League participations== * [[Benin Premier League]]: 2011– * [[Benin Second Division]]: ????–2011 ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/benin/association-sportive-oussou-saka/20791/ Soccerway] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234707/http://teembo.com/Teams/Shields/BJ/AS_Oussou_Saka.jpg Logo] *[http://www.calciozz.it/equipa.php?id=28089&%3bmenu=esc Calciozz] {{Benin Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Benin]] [[Category:Sport in Porto-Novo]] {{Benin-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Ato Boldon Stadium | nickname = | image = TnT Ato Boldon Stadium.jpg | location = [[Couva]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]] | coordinates = {{Coord| 10.424717|-61.417185|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | opened = 2001 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Government of Trinidad and Tobago | operator = Ministry of Sports | surface = Grass | Constructor = Designworks Ltd. | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | nicknames = | tenants = [[Central F.C.]]
[[Club Sando F.C.]]
[[Trinidad and Tobago Football Association]] | seating_capacity = 10,000[http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/tri/ato_boldon_stadium Ato Boldon Stadium] Stadium Database | dimensions = }} The '''Ato Boldon Stadium''' is an athletics and football stadium located in [[Couva]], [[Trinidad and Tobago]]. It is currently the home ground of [[Central F.C.|Central]] and [[Club Sando F.C.|Club Sando]].[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/trinidad-and-tobago/club-sando/34540/ Club Sando] Soccerway[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/trinidad-and-tobago/central-fc/22764/ Central FC] Soccerway ==History== The stadium was constructed for the [[2001 FIFA U-17 World Championship]] which was hosted by Trinidad and Tobago, and was named for eight-time Olympic and World Championship medal winner and 1997 200m World Champion, sprinter [[Ato Boldon]]. It hosted four of the six [[2001 FIFA U-17 World Championship#Group C|Group C matches]]. It was also used for the [[2010 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup]], in which it hosted one match from Group A, one from Group B, four of the Group C matches, one of the quarter-finals and both semi-finals. The stadium played host to a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|World Cup qualifier]] on October 10, 2017, in which Trinidad and Tobago defeated the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]] and prevented them from qualifying for the World Cup.{{cite news |date=10 October 2017 |title=United States miss out on World Cup after Trinidad loss |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-soccer-worldcup-tto-usa/united-states-miss-out-on-world-cup-after-trinidad-loss-idUSKBN1CG080 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=17 January 2018}} Prior to the match, the United States complained of inadequate conditions after the track separating the pitch from the stands was flooded, forcing players to be carried across.{{cite news |last=Nicholas |first=Stephon |date=9 October 2017 |title=Team USA meets 'river' at Ato Boldon Stadium |url=http://newsday.co.tt/2017/10/09/team-usa-meets-river-at-ato-boldon-stadium/ |work=[[Trinidad and Tobago Newsday]] |accessdate=17 January 2018}}{{cite news |last=Baxter |first=Kevin |date=9 October 2017 |title=U.S. World Cup hopes will sink or swim in water-logged Trinidad |url=http://www.latimes.com/sports/soccer/la-sp-us-world-cup-20171009-story.html |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=17 January 2018}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Football venues in Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Trinidad and Tobago]] [[Category:Central F.C.]] {{Trinidad-sports-venue-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=June 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox non Test cricket team | name = Cameroon | image = Cameroon cricket logo.gif | image_size = 140px | caption = | nickname = | association = [[Cameroon Cricket Association]] | icc_status = [[ICC members|Associate member]]{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/news/422449|title=Ireland and Afghanistan ICC newest full members amid wide-ranging governance reform|work=[[International Cricket Council]]|date=22 June 2017|accessdate=1 September 2018}} | icc_member_year = 2017 | icc_region = [[ICC Africa|Africa]] | WCL_division = n/a (regional tournaments) | coach = | captain = | first_match = {{flagicon|Cameroon}} '''Cameroon''' v. {{cr-rt|Lesotho}}
([[Accra]], [[Ghana]]; 25 February 2011) | first_fc = | first_la = | first_t20 = | asofdate = 4 September 2015 }} The '''Cameroon national cricket team''' is the team that represents the [[Republic of Cameroon]] in [[international cricket]]. The team is organised by the [[Cameroon Cricket Association]], which gained affiliate membership of the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC) on 29 June 2007{{cite web |url=http://www.icc-cricket.com/about/177/icc-members/affiliate-members/cameroon |title=Cameroon |accessdate=15 July 2015 |work=ICC}} and became an [[ICC members|associate member]] in 2017. However, the national side did not make its debut until 2011, when it played in the [[2011 ICC World Cricket League Africa Region Twenty20 Division Three|2011 Africa Division Three]] tournament in Ghana.[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/14/14737/Other_Matches.html Other matches played by Cameroon] – CricketArchive. Retrieved 4 September 2015. In April 2018, the ICC decided to grant full [[Twenty20 International]] (T20I) status to all its members. Therefore, all [[Twenty20]] matches played between Cameroon and other [[List of International Cricket Council members|ICC members]] after 1 January 2019 will be a full T20I.{{cite web|url=https://www.icc-cricket.com/media-releases/672322|title=All T20 matches between ICC members to get international status|work=[[International Cricket Council]]|date=26 April 2018|accessdate=1 September 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{National cricket teams}} [[Category:Cricket in Cameroon]] [[Category:National cricket teams]] [[Category:National sports teams of Cameroon|Cricket]] [[Category:Cameroon in international cricket]] {{cameroon-sport-stub}} {{cricket-team-stub}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} '''Indian Match-fixing Investigations (1997)''' summarises the events surrounding the allegations laid by [[Manoj Prabhakar]] of match fixing in a magazine. [[Board of Control for Cricket in India|BCCI]] instituted a commission to examine the charges. Based on lack of evidence, the commission dismissed all allegations .
==Prabhakar's allegations== [[Manoj Prabhakar]] made a public allegation against an unknown team member to the magazine ''[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]'' in June 1997.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.outlookindia.com/full.asp?fodname=19970611&fname=COVER+STORY&sid=2 | title=Prabhakar: 'I was offered Money' | publisher=Outlook India | date=11 June 1997 | accessdate=23 March 2007 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> BCCI instituted a one-man investigation commission headed by retired Chief Justice of India – Honorable [[Yeshwant Vishnu Chandrachud]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/jun/21d.htm | title=Chandrachud committee to probe betting scam | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=21 June 1997 | accessdate=23 March 2007}}</ref> Specifically the following games were brought to light by Manoj Prabhakar as part of his allegations:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/jun/02c.htm | title=Chandrachud committee to probe betting scam | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=2 June 1997 | accessdate=2 April 2007}}</ref>
* India V/s Pakistan in Sharjah in 1991. Even with fading light, the team management asked Prabhakar and [[Sanjay Manjrekar]] to continue playing after the umpires offered light. Pakistan won the match in the last over and qualified for the finals of the trophy. * India V/s Pakistan in Colombo (Singer Cup) in 1994. Manoj Prabhakar was offered Rs 2.5 million for sabotaging the match in Pakistan's favour. Manoj claims to have shouted the player out of his room. The match was washed away due to rain. * India V/s West Indies in Kanpur in 1994. [[Nayan Mongia]] and [[Manoj Prabhakar]] scored 11 runs in 48 balls chasing [[West Indies]] total. Both the players were dropped for the subsequent match on charges of indiscipline * India V/s Pakistan in Sharjah (Date: Unknown). Both the captains [[Aamir Sohail]] and [[Mohammad Azharuddin]] claimed winning the toss.
==Commission hearings==
BCCI wanted the commission to examine the following charges:<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/ju1/01a.htm | title=Chandrachud gets his brief | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=28 June 1997 | accessdate=2 April 2007}}</ref>
* Was there any truth in the allegations by Manoj Prabhakar true? * Was any Indian cricketer, official, journalist or any other person involved in betting and match fixing? * Did [[Ajit Wadekar]] tap the telephones of Indian cricketers? * Was there any truth in the bribery and match-fixing reports?
Justice Chandrachud started his inquiry on 7 July 1997. [[Manoj Prabhakar]], [[Kapil Dev]] and ''[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]'' magazine correspondent Krishna Prasad deposed to the judge on the first day.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/jul/07bet.htm | title=Prabhakar refuses to finger player as Chandrachud begins probe into betting scandal | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=7 July 1997 | accessdate=2 April 2007}}</ref> Manoj Prabhakar did not reveal names or provide evidence of his charges (Match Fixing and Phone Tapping allegation on then Cricket Manager [[Ajit Wadekar]]).<ref name="Chandrachudreport">{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/2000/apr/20report.htm | title=Full Report – '''Chandrachud Commission''' | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=20 April 2000 | accessdate=23 March 2007}}</ref>
Other people who appeared in front of the commission: * 22 July 1997: [[Ajit Wadekar]], [[Ashok Mankad]], [[Dilip Vengsarkar]] and [[Sanjay Manjrekar]]<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/jul/22a.htm | title=Players appear in front of Chandrachud Commission | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=22 July 1997 | accessdate=3 April 2007}}</ref> * 5 September 1997: [[Sachin Tendulkar]], [[Mohammad Azharuddin]], [[Sunil Gavaskar]], [[Nayan Mongia]] and D.V.Subba Rao (Manager – West Indies Tour)<ref>{{cite web | url=http://content-ind.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/74094.html | title=Azhar to discuss betting allegations scandal | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=5 September 1997 | accessdate=3 April 2007}}</ref> * [[Ajay Jadeja]], [[Chandu Borde]], [[Sandeep Patil]], Sunil Dev (Manager – India Tour of South Africa), Makarand Waigankar (Journalist) and Dr. Ali Irani (Physiotherapist) * Aniruddha Bahal (Principal Correspondent, ''[[Outlook (magazine)|Outlook]]''), Lokendra Pratap Sahi (Sports Editor, [[The Telegraph (Kolkata)|The Telegraph]]), Bipin Dani (freelance journalist), SK Sham (Press Correspondent, [[Reuters]]), Pradeep Vijaykar (Assistant Editor, [[The Times of India]]), Pradeep Magazine (Sports Editor, Pioneer), H Natarajan (Sports Editor, [[The Indian Express]]) and R. Mohan ([[The Hindu]]) gave written statements to the commission
==Chandrachud Commission report==
Justice Chandrachud completed his inquiry in October 1997 and submitted the report on an undisclosed date to BCCI. When the match fixing controversy resurfaced in 2000, [[Board of Control for Cricket in India|BCCI]] released the Chandrachud Report to the media. The report concluded:
* There was no plausible reason why Manoj Prabhakar had to wait 3 to 6 years to report match-fixing allegations. [[Sanjay Manjrekar|Manjrekar's]] statement contradicted Prabhakar's on the events at Sharjah in October 1991. No evidence was provided with respect to the Singer Cup incident nor was a report made to the Captain, Coach or Vice-captain. Manoj's allegation against [[Aamir Sohail]] and [[Mohammad Azharuddin]] on the toss incident was factually incorrect as there was no match when these 2 cricketers captained their countries in Sharjah. Manoj Prabhakar refused to name the attempted briber in spite of assurances from the judge himself. The judge concluded that Manoj's allegation was a result of his getting back at Mohammad Azharuddin. The judge had no hesitation in rejecting the allegations made by Manoj Prabhakar.<ref name="Chandrachudreport"/> * The judge accepted [[Ajit Wadekar]]'s statement on the phone-tapping allegation and dismissed the same.<ref name="Chandrachudreport"/> * All of these inferences of journalist of match-fixing were not unjustified as the Judge himself believes that large amount of betting took place on cricket in India. But the Police said that it had not been possible for their investigating teams to identify any player or players in the Indian team who lay bets on cricket.<ref name="Chandrachudreport"/>
==Criticism== There was criticism in the Indian media that the commission did not examine all facts available to it.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/sports/oct/20a.htm | title=Not proven! | publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=20 October 1997 | accessdate=3 April 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://content-usa.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/84505.html | title=Chandrachud report dismissed as `old hat' | publisher=[[Cricinfo]] |date=21 April 2000 | accessdate=3 April 2007}}</ref> Specific areas of concern for the media was the method of recording evidence, lack of initiative to dig into the disconnect in facts of the Aamir Sohail – Mohammad Azharuddin toss, lack of questioning and evidences against people involved in betting and match-fixing, not considering the tapes of interview by ''Outlook'' with Rashead Latif (where he named five Indian cricketers involved in match fixing and which he subsequently backed out).
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
[[Category:Indian cricket in the 20th century]] [[Category:Cricket controversies]]

Reynolds Razorback Stadium''' is an [[American football]] stadium in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas]]{{cite web |url=https://allcountries.org/streetview/view.php?place=300+North+Razorback+Road%2C+Fayetteville%2C+AR+72701 |title=350 North Razorback Road, Fayetteville, AR 72701, Google street view and map |work=allcountries.org/streetview |accessdate=2017-12-30}} and serves as the home field of the [[University of Arkansas]] [[Arkansas Razorbacks|Razorbacks]] football team since its opening in 1938. The stadium was formerly known as '''Razorback Stadium''' since 1941 before being renamed in 2001 in honor of [[Donald W. Reynolds]], an American businessman and philanthropist. The [[playing field]] in the stadium is named the '''Frank Broyles Field''', honoring former Arkansas head football coach and athletic director [[Frank Broyles]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sportingnews.com/ncaa-football/story/2007-11-03/arkansas-names-football-field-after-outgoing-athletic-director-frank-broyles?story-topic-NCAAF=NBA|title=Arkansas names football field after outgoing athletic director Frank Broyles|work=Associated Press|publisher=SportingNews|date=November 4, 2007|accessdate=December 29, 2010}} During the 2000-2001 renovations, Razorback Stadium increased the seating capacity from 50,019{{cite web|title=1999 Schedules/1998 Results|url=http://fs.ncaa.org/Docs/stats/football_records/DI/2000/SkedResults.pdf|publisher=NCAA|accessdate=September 4, 2012}} to 72,000, with an option to expand capacity to 76,000 with the "temporary" bleacher seating atop the south end.{{cite news |url=http://stadiumdb.com/news/2015/09/new_stadiums_old_gray_lady_and_others|title=New stadiums: Old Gray Lady and others|date=September 25, 2015|accessdate=September 25, 2015|work=StadiumDB.com}} ==History== Before 1938, the Razorbacks played in a 300-seat stadium built in 1901 on land on top of "The Hill", which is now occupied by [[Mullins Library]] and the Fine Arts Center (in the "center" of campus). The new stadium cost approximately $492,000 and was funded by the [[Works Progress Administration]], with the University of Arkansas only paying 22% of the contact.{{cite book |title=Chemical Engineering at the University of Arkansas: A Centennial History, 1902-2002|author=Martin, Michael S.|isbn=0-9713470-0-X|publisher=University of Arkansas Press|year=2002|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VlXJIRMcSmAC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|location=Fayetteville}}{{cite news |title=Firms line up for UA stadium project. (Razorback Stadium in Arkansas)|work=Arkansas Business|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/21233084.html|publisher=Entrepreneur|date=October 12, 1998|accessdate=December 29, 2010}}{{cite news |title=Best And Worst Of 1998|work=Arkansas Business|publisher=Arkansas Business|date=September 28, 1998}} The stadium opened for the [[1938 college football season|1938 football season]] as University Stadium, holding a capacity of 13,500 spectators. In the home opener for the Razorbacks, the Razorbacks defeated [[Oklahoma State Cowboys football|Oklahoma A&M]] by a score of 27–7 on September 24, 1938. The following week, Arkansas dedicated the stadium to then sitting Arkansas Governor [[Carl Edward Bailey|Carl E. Bailey]] on October 3, 1938, changing the name of the stadium to Bailey Stadium. Following Governor Bailey's defeat in the 1940 gubernatorial election to [[Homer Martin Adkins]], the stadium's name was changed in 1941 to Razorback Stadium.{{cite book |title=The University of Arkansas Razorback Band: A History, 1874-2004|year=2004|location=Fayetteville|publisher=University of Arkansas Press|author=Thompson, T.T. Tyler|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vldxGLeYmUYC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=57|isbn= 1-55728-779-1}} ===Renovation=== [[File:09-02-06-RRS-PigScreen.jpg|thumb|left|The "PigScreen", a 30 by 107 foot [[LED]] display that was installed in 2000.]] Athletic director Frank Broyles began searching for architects for the proposed $65 million stadium expansion and renovation in 1998, believing that the renovation was needed in order for the Razorbacks to compete in the Southeastern Conference at a consistent level.{{cite book|title=Hogs! The Story of Razorbacks Football|author=Schroeder, George|page=207|isbn=0-7432-8052-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3c5sVvB0ihQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2005|publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=New York}} Broyles hoped for a completion date of 2000 or 2001 and narrowed the search down to three architecture firms: [[Peter Eisenman|Eisenman Architects]] of [[New York, New York|New York]], [[Heery International]] of [[Atlanta]] and [[Rosser International]] of Atlanta. Broyles awarded the renovation contract to Heery International with local support from the Wittenberg, DeLoney and Davidson architecture firm of Fayetteville.{{cite news|url=http://thecabin.net/stories/080599/spo_0805990026.html|title=Razorback Stadium going uptown|author=Allen, Nate|work=Log Cabin|date=August 5, 1999|accessdate=December 29, 2010}} The renovation was partly funded by the [[Donald W. Reynolds]] Foundation, when the foundation donated $21 million in 1999 to help renovate the stadium.{{cite news |title=$10 Million Grant From Donald W. Reynolds Foundation Brings New Life to Vol Walker Hall|work=University of Arkansas Relations|date=May 13, 2010}} What was then the largest [[LED]] display in a sports venue, the 30 by 107 foot screen produced by [[SmartVision]] was installed along with a new scoreboard at the northern end zone in 2000. The expansion was completed before the beginning of the [[2001 NCAA Division I-A football season|2001 football season]], increasing the permanent seating capacity to 72,000 from its previous capacity of 51,000 seats. 4,000 bleacher seats were added in the south end zone upper deck bringing capacity to just over 76,000 with the new expansion. In honor of the Reynolds Foundation's generosity, the stadium was formally renamed Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium on September 8, 2001, where Arkansas lost to [[University of Tennessee|Tennessee]] by a score of 13–3. On November 3, 2007, the date of the last Fayetteville home game of the 2007 football season, the playing field was dedicated and named in honor of outgoing athletic director Broyles.{{cite news |url=http://scores.espn.go.com/ncf/recap?gameId=273070008|title=McFadden rushes for SEC-record 323 yards as Arkansas rolls|date=November 3, 2007|accessdate=December 29, 2010|work=Associated Press|publisher=ESPN}} A major renovation to the stadium was proposed in 2011 by Athletic Director Jeff Long, unveiling the plans to enclose the north end zone. The proposed renovation is estimated at $78 million to $95 million, which would feature at least 5,000 new seats, including field-level suites and indoor and outdoor club areas.{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/college-sports/story/_/id/7120140/arkansas-unveils-300-million-plan-expansion-athletic-facilities|title=Arkansas unveils athletic facilities plan|date=October 18, 2011|accessdate=April 26, 2012|work=Associated Press|publisher=ESPN}} A new upgrade to the stadium for the 2012 season increased the size to 38 by 167 feet, from the previous LED screen size of 30 by 107 feet. The upgrade was contracted through [[LSI Industries]].{{cite news|url=http://www.insidevandy.com/drupal/node/15269|title=Stadium Preview: Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium|author=Kuhlenschmidt, Jack|work=The Vanderbilt Hustler|publisher=InsideVandy|date=October 28, 2010|accessdate=December 29, 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.arkansasrazorbacks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=6100&ATCLID=205429572|title=New Video Display for Razorback Stadium|work=Athletic Media Relations|publisher=ArkansasRazorbacks.com|date=May 21, 2012|accessdate=August 25, 2012}} During the 2016–17 offseason, the Broyles Athletic Center was demolished as part of a $160 million renovation and expansion of the stadium. The expansion will add 4,800 seats and new premium seating to the north end zone.{{cite web|title=Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium Renovation|url=http://arkansasrazorbacks.com/dwrrs/|publisher=Arkansas Razorbacks Athletics|accessdate=2 May 2017}}{{not in ref|date=May 2018}} This expansion will boost the capacity of the stadium from 76,000 (with south end zone top bleachers) to 80,800. {{citation needed|date=May 2018}} However, since bleachers are no longer being used on the roof of the south end zone, official capacity beginning with the 2018 season, as relayed to the university's board of trustees prior to its vote to approve the expansion project, will be 76,212. The increase in capacity is fewer than 4,800 seats because some club seating on the east side was eliminated to add additional suites.{{cite web|title=Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium -- Trustee Questions|url=http://arkansasrazorbacks.com/dwrrs-original/questions.html|publisher=Arkansas Razorbacks Athletics|access date=29 July 2018 ==Controversy== {{see also|War Memorial Stadium (Arkansas)}} Since 1948, home games were divided between two venues: Razorback Stadium and [[War Memorial Stadium (Arkansas)|War Memorial Stadium]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]]. Because of the stadium renovations in 1999-2000, Razorbacks athletic director Frank Broyles wanted to move all home games to Razorback Stadium to help pay off the $30 million bond. Broyles pointed out that the expanded Razorback Stadium would increase revenue to $3 million per game, compared to the $2 million per game for playing at War Memorial Stadium.{{cite news|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/tradejournals/article/64153344.html|date=July 24, 2000|accessdate=December 29, 2010|title=Broyles' Power: Fierce or Fading?|work=Arkansas Business Publishing Group|publisher=Entrepreneur}} However, Little Rock investors did not like the idea of moving all home games to Fayetteville and countered with an offer to renovate and expand War Memorial Stadium to increase revenue. Also, Little Rock investor Warren Stephens threatened to discontinue his family's support ($150,000 in annual donations with an additional $1 million in annual support from his family's company [[Stephens Inc.]]) for the program if games were pulled from Little Rock. After listening to both [[Chuck Neinas]] (Broyles' consultant on the issue) and Stephens in January 2000, the University of Arkansas Board of Trustees voted 9-1 to sign a compromised contract with the owners of War Memorial Stadium. The contract would keep at least two Razorbacks games, with one being a conference game, in Little Rock until the end of the 2014 season.{{cite book|title=Hogs! The Story of Razorbacks Football|author=Schroeder, George|page=208|isbn=0-7432-8052-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3c5sVvB0ihQC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=2005|publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=New York}} In 2008, the contract with War Memorial Stadium was extended through the 2016 football season by athletic director [[Jeff Long (athletic director)|Jeff Long]]. As of 2014, a new five-year contract calls for only one game to be played at War Memorial Stadium each season through 2018. In 2014 and 2018, the game will be a conference opponent. In 2015, 2016, and 2017 the game will be versus a non-conference team. 2018 will mark the 75th anniversary of the Razorbacks playing in War Memorial Stadium.{{cite web |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722170120/http://thecabin.net/stories/082308/spo_0823080040.shtml|title=Razorbacks sign two-year War Memorial Extension|date=August 23, 2008|accessdate=November 25, 2010}} ==Other uses== The movie ''[[Greater (film)|Greater]]'' (2016). ==Gallery== Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium, LSU at Arkansas, 2012.jpg|Seating behind the Razorback sideline Image:09-02-06-RazorbacksEnterRSS.jpg|The Razorback football team takes the field Image:09-02-06-UArkBand-A.jpg|The Razorback Marching Band in formation ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.arkansasrazorbacks.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=6100&ATCLID=187018 Arkansas Razorbacks Official Site Donald W. Reynolds Razorback Stadium Overview] * [https://maps.google.com/maps?q=fayetteville,+ar&hl=en&t=h&ll=36.068059,-94.178839&spn=0.004041,0.013475&t=h Google Maps Satellite Image/Map of Donald W. Reynolds] {{University of Arkansas}} {{Arkansas Razorbacks football navbox}} {{Southeastern Conference football venue navbox}} {{Arkansas college football venues}} [[Category:1938 establishments in Arkansas]] [[Category:Arkansas Razorbacks football venues]] [[Category:American football venues in Arkansas]] [[Category:University of Arkansas buildings]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Fayetteville, Arkansas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1938]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Everlast Worldwide Incorporated | logo = Everlast-logo-2011.svg | logo_size = 200px | founder = Jacob Golomb | type = [[Subsidiary]] | traded_as = | foundation = [[The Bronx]], [[New York City]], New York, U.S.
({{start date and age|1910}}) | location_city = [[New York City]], New York | location_country = U.S. | locations = | key_people = | area_served = Worldwide | industry = [[Sporting goods]] | products = Boxing, MMA equipment & apparel | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | num_employees = | parent = [[Sports Direct]] | homepage = {{URL|http://www.everlast.com/}} }} '''Everlast''' (stylized as '''EVERLAST''') is an American brand of boxing, mixed martial arts and fitness-related equipment, [[clothing]], [[footwear]], and [[fashion accessory|accessories]]. It markets its products worldwide. The company was founded in the Bronx and is now based in Manhattan. In 2007, the company was acquired by the British retailing group [[Sports Direct]]. == History == In 1910, 17-year-old Jacob Golomb, the son of a tailor and an avid swimmer, started the company as a manufacturer of swimwear designed to last longer than previously available swimsuits; he guaranteed his suits would last longer than one year, and named them "Everlast".{{cite news |first=Alan |last=Feuer |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/11/01/nyregion/everlast-to-close-plant-in-bronx-100-workers-to-lose-their-jobs.html |title=Everlast to Close Plant in Bronx; 100 Workers to Lose Their Jobs |newspaper=The New York Times |date=November 1, 2003 |accessdate=2017-11-21 }}{{cite news |first=Timothy |last=Williams |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/04/24/nyregion/24everlast.html |title=After a Boxing Giant's Departure From the Bronx, a Tiny Contender Steps Up |newspaper=The New York Times |date=April 24, 2006 |accessdate=2017-11-21 }} Everlast expanded into supplying a wide range of sports equipment. The company first produced boxing gear in 1917 after a young [[Jack Dempsey]] asked them to supply him with headgear that would last for more than 15 rounds. It subsequently sponsored [[Roberto Duran]], [[Joe Frazier]], [[Marvin Hagler]], [[Larry Holmes]], [[Sugar Ray Leonard]], and in particular [[Muhammad Ali]] and became the most recognizable boxing brand.{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Van Riper |url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/11/09/everlast-boxing-reyes-business-sports-everlast.html |title=Everlast Tries To Get Back In The Fight |newspaper=Forbes |date=November 9, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091113083159/http://www.forbes.com/2009/11/09/everlast-boxing-reyes-business-sports-everlast.html |archivedate=November 13, 2009 }} Golomb died in the 1950s and was succeeded as head of the company by his son Daniel, who made the Everlast logo on the company's boxing gloves larger to increase visibility on television. Ben Nadorf purchased 50% of Everlast Sports Mfg. Corp in 1958 and became sole owner in 1995. In 2000, the company was acquired by George Horowitz's Active Apparel Group, which had manufactured men's and women's sportswear under license for Everlast,{{cite news |first=Reid |last=Cherner |url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/sports/boxing/2004-10-18-everlast-cover_x.htm |title=Boxing: Everlast still a knockout 94 years later |newspaper=USA Today |date=October 19, 2004 |accessdate=2017-11-21 }} and in 2007, Sports Direct acquired Everlast Worldwide.{{Cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/2811245/Mike-Ashley-agrees-to-buy-Everlast.html |title=Mike Ashley agrees to buy Everlast |newspaper=The Telegraph |last=Bland |first=Ben |date=June 29, 2007 |access-date=2017-11-21}}{{cite news |first=Philip |last=Aldrick |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/2819137/Sports-Direct-sells-stake-in-Amer.html |title=Sports Direct sells stake in Amer |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=November 8, 2007 |accessdate=2017-11-21}} The company has expanded its activities into [[Mixed martial arts|MMA]] and has been awarded the World MMA Award for Best Technical Equipment Brand five times, most recently in 2016.{{citation needed|date=November 2017}} Everlast boxing equipment is made in a factory in [[Moberly, Missouri]]; other products are manufactured outside the US by licensees. The company also made boxing equipment at a factory in the [[Port Morris, Bronx|Port Morris]] section of the Bronx from the 1980s until 2003. == Products == {{unreferenced section|date=November 2017}} Everlast produces a large quantity of boxing and MMA gloves for all types of training, and boxing-related equipment such as heavy bags, speed bags, and headgear. The company has granted a large number of licenses for products including men's and women's athletic apparel, sports-nutrition products, and athletic footwear. Everlast has trademarked technologies that cushion the hands and wrist (EverGel), regulate body temperature (EverCool), wick away moisture (EverDri), and fight the growth of bacteria and microbes (EverFresh). Everlast provides equipment for reality TV shows like ''[[The Contender (TV series)|The Contender]]'' and ''[[The Biggest Loser (U.S. TV series)|The Biggest Loser]]'', as well as fitness magazines and feature films. Everlast's MX professional line of boxing glove (pro fight gloves). == Media == {{unreferenced section|date=November 2017}} Everlast is responsible for the production and syndication of a number of podcasts, including ''The Fight Cave MMA Podcast'', ''Talkbox'', ''In Fighting Shape'', ''Protect Yourself at all Times'', and ''Evolving Athletes''. ==See also== {{portal|Boxing|MMA}} *[[Lonsdale (clothing)]] *[[Mixed martial arts clothing]] ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == *{{Commons category-inline|Everlast Worldwide}} * {{official website|http://www.everlast.com}} [[Category:Companies based in New York City]] [[Category:Clothing companies established in 1910]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Manufacturing companies established in 1910]] [[Category:1910 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports Direct]] [[Category:Port Morris, Bronx]]

{{Infobox film | name = Five to Nil | image =File:Five to Nil.jpg | image_size = | caption = | director = [[Mario Bonnard]] | producer = [[Giuseppe Amato]] | writer = Mario Bonnard
[[Michele Galdieri]] | narrator = | starring = [[Angelo Musco (actor)|Angelo Musco]]
[[Milly (actress)|Milly]]
[[Osvaldo Valenti]] | music = [[Giulio Bonnard]]
[[Dan Caslar]] | cinematography = [[Ferdinando Martini (cinematographer)|Ferdinando Martini]] | editing = Mario Bonnard | studio = JHA Film | distributor = [[Caesar Film]] | released = 1932 | runtime = 70 minutes | country = Italy | language = [[Italian language|Italian]] | budget = | gross = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | website = }} '''''Five to Nil''''' (Italian: '''''Cinque a zero''''') is a 1932 Italian [[sports film|sports]] [[comedy film]] directed by [[Mario Bonnard]] and starring [[Angelo Musco (actor)|Angelo Musco]], [[Milly (actress)|Milly]] and [[Osvaldo Valenti]].Moliterno p.5 It was inspired by a 5-0 victory by [[A.S. Roma]] against their rivals [[Juventus]] in 1931. It was shot at the studios of [[Caesar Film]] and included scenes featuring the real-life Roma players. ==Synopsis== The president of a football club becomes concerned that his captain is spending too much time romancing a celebrated nightclub singer and not enough on training. ==Cast== * [[Angelo Musco (actor)|Angelo Musco]] as Presidente della società calcistica * [[Milly (actress)|Milly]] as Billie Grac, a singer * [[Osvaldo Valenti]] as Barenghi * [[Franco Coop]] as Direttore d'Orchestra dell'Eden * [[Mario Siletti]] as Professore di Matematica * [[Luciano Molinari]] as Direttore del Teatro * [[Maurizio D'Ancora]] as Masseur * [[Oreste Bilancia]] as Masseur * [[Tina Lattanzi]] as Moglie del Presidente * [[Aristide Garbini]] as Membro del Club * [[Umberto Sacripante]] as Membro del Club * [[Maria Donati]] as Spectator * [[Giorgio Bianchi (director)|Giorgio Bianchi]] as Executive * Armando Fineschi as Executive * [[Mario Colli]] as Executive * [[Augusto Bandini]] as Augusto * [[Camillo Pilotto]] as Augusto's Deputy * [[Niní Gordini Cervi]] as Billie's sister * Ugo Fasano as Trainer * [[Totò Mignone]] as Assistant Coach * [[Attilio Ferraris]] as Himself *[[Fulvio Bernardini]] as Himself *[[Arturo Chini Ludueña]] as Himself *[[Bruno Dugoni]] as Himself *[[Fernando Eusebio]] as Himself *[[Cesare Augusto Fasanelli]] as Himself *[[Guido Masetti]] as Himself *[[Attilio Mattei]] as Himself *[[Rodolfo Volk]] as Himself == References == == Bibliography == * Moliterno, Gino. ''Historical Dictionary of Italian Cinema''. Scarecrow Press, 2008. == External links == * {{IMDb title|0022766}} {{Mario Bonnard}} [[Category:1930s comedy films]] [[Category:Italian comedy films]] [[Category:1930s sports films]] [[Category:Italian sports films]] [[Category:1932 films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:Italian-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Mario Bonnard]] [[Category:Association football films]] [[Category:Films set in Rome]] {{1930s-Italy-comedy-film-stub}} {{sport-film-stub}}

[[Xalapa]], [[Veracruz]], 91040 | coordinates = | broke_ground = 2001 | opened = 2003 | owner = [[Universidad Veracruzana]] | operator = [[Universidad Veracruzana]] | construction_cost = [[Mexican peso|$]]2 Million | architect = [[FAUV]] | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = [[Pakal|Constructora Pakal]] | tenants = [[Halcones UV Xalapa]]

It was created when the city of Xalapa was granted an expansion team, and the Universidad Veracruzana offered its recently{{when|date=April 2017}} planned arena to the team for its use. {{coord missing|Veracruz}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Mexico]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Mexico]] [[Category:2003 establishments in Mexico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2003]]

revision.text:
{{Coord|50.871|-0.741|region:GB_scale:5000|display=title}} {{Infobox cricket team | name = Goodwood Cricket Club | image = [[Image:Goodwood Cricket Club (emblem).jpg|200px|Goodwood Cricket Club's emblem]] | oneday_name = | second_team = | coach = ''None'' | bowlingcoach = | fielding_coach = | captain = James Mayne | od_captain = | overseas = | colors = Red and Yellow {{color box|Red}} {{color box|Yellow}} | founded = 1702 | ground = [[Goodwood House|Goodwood Park]] | capacity = | owner = His Grace [[The Duke of Richmond]] and Gordon | ceo = Richard Geffen | adviser = | first_fc = | first_fc_year = | first_fc_venue = | title1 = | title1wins = | title2 = | title2wins = | title3 = | title3wins = | title4 = | title4wins = | website =http://www.goodwood.play-cricket.com Goodwood Website }}
'''Goodwood Cricket Club''' is a Sunday village cricket team that play during the summer in the grounds of Goodwood Park, near [[Chichester]]. The ground overlooks [[Goodwood House]] and is owned by the Duke of Richmond and Gordon.
It is thought to be one of the oldest [[cricket]] clubs in the world.{{Citation needed|date=November 2010}} It had strong links with [[Lord's]], as the 4th [[Duke]] was one of the original backers of [[Thomas Lord]].
Today, the club and ground is owned by the Duke of Richmond and Gordon but run by a group of [[volunteering|volunteers]] that make up the Goodwood Cricket Club . The Club has formed an alliance with Chichester Priory Park Cricket Club and their 1st and 2nd XIs play at the ground on Saturdays.
==History ==
A receipt for [[brandy]], given to the players, records Goodwood's earliest known game in 1702. [[Image:Goodwood Cricket Club cricket pitch.jpg|thumb|280px|left|A view from the club pavilion, overlooking Goodwood House]] In 1727 in Goodwood Park, a game was played between the 2nd Duke of Richmond and Mr Brodrick of Peper Harow Park, near Godalming (cricket is still played there today). As was common in those days there was a wager on the match and a set of rules was drawn up. These rules are the oldest set of written cricket rules in existence, today, in the world. The originals are kept in Goodwood House, with a copy in the club pavilion and at Lord's. The Club has a strong link with Lord's. The 4th Duke, was one of the original backers of Thomas Lord when he bought 'the rough piece of land' in St John's Wood and the 5th Duke was President of the MCC. The present Duke was President/Patron of Sussex CCC for 25 years. Another link with Lord's could be the club colours. These colours are the racing colours of the Dukes of Richmond, circa 1801. Sometime after their use by the Dukes, and the cricket club, they also became the colours of the MCC circa 1888. Although they could also have links to the Nicholson’s Gin Company. For much of the clubs history the enormous Cedar of Lebanon tree has looked on such players as James Lillywhite, Captain of England (employee of the Duke) and in more recent times Ray Lindwall, Sir Colin Cowdrey, Ted Dexter, Jim Parks, John Snow, Graham Gooch, Nasser Hussain, Devon Malcolm, Gladstone Small, Simon Jones, Adam Hollioake, Nick Compton and Sam Robson to name but a few. The tree was planted as a seed in 1752 and planted out on the ground in 1756. There has been one 1st class match at Goodwood, this was played on 22-23 July 1814 between Lord F Beauclerk’s XI and G Osbaldeston’s XI. The match was scheduled for three days but was over in two. A total of 265 runs were scored in 4 innings, 44 wickets taken and G Osbaldeston’s XI won by 17 runs.
==Related people==
The club has played host to a variety of players, including:
*[[James Lillywhite]], Captain of England (employee of the Duke) * [[Sir Colin Cowdrey]] * [[Ted Dexter]] * [[Jim Parks, Jr.|Jim Parks]] * [[John Snow (cricketer)|John Snow]] * [[Roy Castle]] * [[Allan Wells]] * [[Ian Salisbury]] * [[Graham Gooch]] * [[Nasser Hussain]] * [[Adam Zampa ]] * [[Ray Lindwall]] * [[Devon Malcolm]] * [[Gladstone Small]] * [[Simon Jones (cricketer)|Simon Jones]] * [[Adam Hollioake]] * [[Nick Compton]] * [[Sam Robson]]
==Club developments== [[Image:goodwoodtree.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The Ceder of Lebanon Tree that overlooks the club]] An enormous [[Lebanon Cedar]] tree overlooks the club; it was planted in 1752 as a seed and planted out on the ground in 1756.
===Grounds=== Recent developments have seen the arrival of electric and a bar in 1989, showers in 1991, sightscreens and an enlarged social area in 1996, a new artificial net in 1997, a new scoreboard in 1998, a 3-ton roller in 1999, a roll-on roll-off covers in 2000, additional flat sheet covers in 2015 and a brand new roller in 2016. The square and pavilion are all maintained by voluntary help with support from the Estate.
===Technologies=== *Major updates to the existing website.<ref>[http://goodwood.play-cricket.com GWCC Website]</ref> *A photo gallery of previous matches, using a photo-sharing website, [[photobucket|Photo Bucket]].<ref>[http://www.photobucket.com/gwcc Photobucket Site]</ref> *A [[Twitter]] page, providing members with quick news updates/club news.<ref>[https://twitter.com/goodwoodcc Twitter Page]</ref> *A [[Facebook]] page, was set up in 2010 to try to keep members and fans updated with news via a new social media platform.<ref>[http://www.facebook.com/?ref=logo#!/group.php?gid=343229332853&ref=ts Facebook Site]</ref>
==Recent activity==
==Special games & events==
[[Image:gwccteam2008pic.jpg|thumb|380px|right|The Goodwood Cricket Team of 2008]]
One of the oldest fixtures is the all day game against London New Zealand which was first played in 1955. 2016 saw the reinstatement of a match against the Duke of Richmond's XI organised and captained by his grandsons.
<gallery> Image:gwccpavilion.jpg|The Club Pavilion Image:gwccplaying1.jpg|Goodwood Cricket Team Member batting Image:gwccplaying2.jpg|Goodwood Cricket Team fielding </gallery>

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{hatnote|For the speedway stadium, see [[Hyde Road (speedway)]]. For the railway station, see [[Hyde Road railway station]].}} {{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Hyde Road | image = [[File:Hyderoad1909OSmap.png|150px]] | fullname = Hyde Road | location = [[Ardwick]], [[Manchester]], England | built = 1887 | opened = 17 September 1887 | closed = 1923 | demolished = 1923 | owner = Manchester City F.C., Chesters Brewery | seating_capacity = 40,000 | tenants = [[Manchester City F.C.]] (1887–1923) | dimensions = unknown }} {{coord|53|28|10|N|2|12|32|W|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}}
'''Hyde Road''' was a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[West Gorton]], [[Manchester]], England. It was home to [[Manchester City F.C.]] and their predecessors from its construction in 1887 until 1923, when the club moved to [[Maine Road]]. It was named after [[A57 road#Manchester - Sheffield|Hyde Road]], a road which begins at the east end of Ardwick Green South in [[Ardwick]] and runs east towards [[Hyde, Greater Manchester|Hyde]]. At the boundary between Gorton and [[Denton, Greater Manchester|Denton]] it continues as Manchester Road.<ref>''Geographia Manchester Colour Map''. London: Geographia, 1986 {{ISBN|0-09-218190-2}}</ref>
Before its use as a football ground, the site was an area of waste ground, and in its early days the ground had only rudimentary facilities. The first stand was built in 1888, but the ground had no changing facilities until 1896; players had to change in a nearby public house, the Hyde Road Hotel. By 1904 the ground had developed into a 40,000-capacity venue, hosting an [[FA Cup]] semi-final between [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|The Wednesday]] the following year.
The stands and terraces were arranged in a haphazard manner due to space constraints, and by 1920 the club had outgrown the cramped venue. A decision to seek an alternative venue was hastened in November 1920, when the Main Stand was destroyed by fire. Manchester City moved to the 80,000-capacity [[Maine Road]] in 1923, and Hyde Road was demolished shortly afterward. One structure from the ground is still in use in the 21st century, a section of roofing which was sold for use at [[The Shay]], a stadium in [[Halifax, West Yorkshire|Halifax]].
==History== From the club's inception in 1880, Manchester City - first known as St Mark's (West Gorton), then as West Gorton A.F.C. and by mid-1884 as just Gorton A.F.C. - [[early grounds of Manchester City F.C.|had struggled to find]] a stable location to base themselves. Originally simply playing on a dangerously bumpy patch of grass near to the church of their origin, the club quickly signed an agreement to ground-share with the Kirkmanshulme Cricket Club before being turfed out only a year later. Three further pitches were then created on wasteland over the following four seasons, but all proved inadequate for one reason or another. When their fifth pitch arrangement collapsed in 1887, with the landlord of the Bulls Head Hotel demanding a rent increase for the use of a nearby field, the club were forced to seek an alternative venue.<ref name="CR82">James, ''Manchester City – The Complete Record'', p82</ref> Then-captain Kenneth McKenzie discovered an area of waste ground on Hyde Road in [[Ardwick]] and near to his place of work, and informed the club committee.<ref name="Inglis">Inglis, ''The Football Grounds of Great Britain'' (2nd ed.), p62</ref> [[Lawrence Furniss]], the club secretary, ascertained that the ground was owned by the Manchester, Sheffield and Lincolnshire Railway Company. Following an initial letter of enquiry by Gorton player Walter Chew to railway company estate agent Edwin Barker,<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p16</ref> Furniss and Chew negotiated a seven-month lease at a cost of £10,<ref name="CR82"/> and the club changed its name to "Ardwick A.F.C." to reflect the new location. A few weeks later, using materials provided by the nearby Galloway engineering works,<ref name="Ward6">Ward, ''The Manchester City Story'', p6</ref> a rudimentary football ground was ready for use. The ground had no changing rooms, and teams changed in a nearby [[public house]], the Hyde Road Hotel, where the football club held business meetings. The ground's first seating area was built in 1888, with 1,000 seats,<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p18</ref> paid for by Chesters Brewery in return for the right to be the sole provider of alcohol inside the ground.<ref name="Ward6"/> Ardwick were admitted to the [[Football League]] in 1892. The first league match held at Hyde Road was a 7–0 Ardwick win against [[Bootle F.C.|Bootle]] on 3 September 1892.<ref>Ward, ''The Manchester City Story'', p8</ref> Two years later the club reformed as "Manchester City F.C."
[[File:Hyderoadcapacity.PNG|thumb|left|From less than 5,000 in 1887, Hyde Road's capacity reached 40,000 by 1904.]] The increasing popularity of the football club resulted in improvements being made to the ground on several occasions. Improvements costing £600 were made in 1890, and changing rooms were provided in 1896.<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p32</ref> A new stand was purchased for £1,500 in 1898, and £2,000 worth of improvements were made in 1904, resulting in a capacity of 40,000 with stands on three sides.<ref>Ward, ''The Manchester City Story'', p12</ref> This development resulted in Hyde Road being chosen to host two prestigious matches—an inter-league match between the English League and the Irish League, and an [[FA Cup]] semi-final between [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] and [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|The Wednesday]].<ref>James, ''Manchester City – The Complete Record'', p84</ref> In 1910 multi-span roofing was built on the three previously uncovered sides of the ground, resulting in covered accommodation for 35,000 spectators.<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p77</ref>
Even though improvements were made the ground suffered problems when hosting large crowds, due to narrow surrounding streets and a shortage of [[turnstile]]s.<ref name="J88"/> A reporter for the ''Manchester Football News'' summarised the access problems: "The croft is a nightmare in wet weather, and altogether the approach is easily the worst of any I know".<ref>Collins, ''All-round Genius'', p95</ref> On occasion, further problems occurred inside the ground as well as outside. A 1913 cup tie against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] drew a crowd officially recorded as 41,709, but believed to be significantly higher. An hour before kick-off the gates were closed, with many ticket-holders unable to gain admission. The crowd was so large that once the match kicked off the crowd began to spill onto the pitch, a problem which worsened as the game progressed. Sunderland's [[Charlie Buchan|Charles Buchan]] recalled that "Before half-time they were three or four yards inside the touchlines." A Sunderland goal in the 58th minute caused further encroachment, forcing the referee to abandon the match.<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', pp83–84</ref> An FA inquiry into the events on the terraces gave rise to debate on the issue of crowd control at sporting events. Use of mounted police was a particularly contentious issue, the chairman of the committee asking "If the ball struck a horse, and the creature plunged among the people, who was to be held responsible for any injuries that might accrue?"<ref>Ward, ''The Manchester City Story'', p20</ref> For years the club contemplated moving but between 1912 and 1914 renowned football stadium architect [[Archibald Leitch]] worked with the club to remodel the Hyde Road site.<ref>Athletic News, 9 June 1913.</ref>
[[File:Shay Stadium, Halifax.jpg|thumb|right|[[The Shay]], Halifax, in 2006. The left hand portion of the pictured stand's roof was originally used at Hyde Road.]] During the suspension of competitive football in the [[First World War]], Hyde Road's redevelopment was put on hold and the venue was used to stable 300 horses.<ref name="Inglis"/> Later in the wartime period the club became the sole leaseholder of the ground, no longer dependent upon support from Chesters brewery. At this point the annual rent was £500.<ref>Ward, ''The Manchester City Story'', p21</ref> In 1920, the ground became the first football venue outside London to be visited by a reigning monarch; [[George V of the United Kingdom|King George V]] attended the ground to watch a match between Manchester City and [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/default.sps?syndicatorguid={7EB24EFC-E397-48B3-977A-BC40E4795300}&rmasiteinstanceguid={5B147D34-2BCF-448D-976C-AE1944ED09F5}&pagegid={20E7C2B7-4832-46D1-B772-AB8CCA2FD0D5}&pcpageid=14773 |title=Stadium History |accessdate=15 June 2008 |publisher=Manchester City FC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930184906/http://www.mcfc.co.uk/default.sps?syndicatorguid=%7B7EB24EFC-E397-48B3-977A-BC40E4795300%7D&rmasiteinstanceguid=%7B5B147D34-2BCF-448D-976C-AE1944ED09F5%7D&pagegid=%7B20E7C2B7-4832-46D1-B772-AB8CCA2FD0D5%7D&pcpageid=14773 |archivedate=30 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In November a fire caused by a cigarette end destroyed the Main Stand, and Manchester City began to seek a new home. Initial discussions raised the possibility of sharing [[Old Trafford (football)|Old Trafford]] with neighbours [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]], but United's proposed rent was prohibitive, so repair work was undertaken and Manchester City continued to play at Hyde Road.<ref name="MGC480">James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p480</ref>
Plans for the club to move to a new ground—[[Maine Road]]—in [[Moss Side]] were announced in 1922. The final Manchester City match at Hyde Road was a league fixture against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 28 April 1923,<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p104</ref> and in August 1923 a public practice game was the last football match played at Hyde Road.<ref name="MGC480"/> Manchester City began the [[1923-24 in English football|1923–24 season]] at Maine Road, which had an 80,000 capacity. Parts of Hyde Road were used elsewhere; the roof of the Main Stand was sold to [[Halifax Town F.C.|Halifax Town]], and erected at [[The Shay]], where even in the 21st century, part of the Hyde Road roof is still in place.<ref>Clayton, ''Everything under the blue moon'', p107</ref> Within a decade, all traces of the football ground had disappeared from Hyde Road. The bulk of the area was taken over by Manchester Corporation Tramways department, whose major Hyde Road depot and works was alongside, for use as their Permanent Way yard for assembling and storing tramway rails and materials. The Tramways system also provided at this time a substantial parcels handling service within the city, using both vans and special parcels trams, and a new central parcels depot was built on the Bennett Street side of the former site, against the railway viaduct. After the end of Manchester's trams in 1949 (most of the old trams were scrapped on this site) it was used for storing old buses and as a bus drivers' training area. As of 2000, the site of the pitch is Olympic Freight Terminal, a container storage and warehousing facility.<ref>Clayton, ''Everything under the blue moon'', p108</ref>
==Layout and structure== For certain areas of the ground few photographs survive, however, a map dating from 1894 indicates that most of the terracing was of uneven shape, and that unusually, a section of railway line leading to a neighbouring boilerworks ran between the terrace and the pitch at one corner of the ground. The main grandstand (the "Main Stand") was situated at the north of the ground. Built in 1889 for £1,500, this structure replaced the original 1,000 capacity grandstand which had been built in 1888. The new grandstand comprised an upper tier of seating and a lower paddock. Most contemporary sources listed the capacity as 4,000, though it is unclear whether this refers to the [[seating capacity]] or the total capacity.<ref name=J87>James, ''Manchester City – The Complete Record'', p87</ref> The wooden stand was gutted by fire in 1920, causing the loss of both the stand and the club records, which were stored within.<ref name="Inglis"/>
The north-eastern end of the ground was known as the "Galloway End". It was intersected by a railway loop leading to the Galloway boilerworks. One part of the terracing was known as the "Boys Stand". This was a separate structure, slightly removed from the rest of the ground and positioned behind the railway loop line which transported boilers from Galloways Boiler Works.<ref>James, ''Manchester City – The Complete Record'', First Edition, p. 100–101</ref> The opposing end, known as the "Stone Yard Stand" or "Hotel End", was another part of the ground with an irregular shape. It consisted of a mixture of seats and terracing, and became the most important seating area in the period following the Main Stand fire.<ref name=J87/> The fourth side was a simple terrace, with a roof covering three-quarters of its length. It had a larger capacity than the other parts of the ground, and was therefore known as "The Popular Side".<ref name=J88>James, ''Manchester City – The Complete Record'', p88</ref> Part of the terrace stood back-to-back with a row of houses on Bennett Street; though the ground was named Hyde Road, its proximity to Bennett Street meant that for some supporters the names Hyde Road and Bennett Street were synonymous.
==Hyde Road Hotel== Adjacent to the ground was the Hyde Road Hotel, a public house in which the players got changed before the matches at the Hyde Road stadium. It served as the venue for several important events in the club's history, such as first meeting of Ardwick A.F.C. on 30 August 1887, and the 1894 decision to form Manchester City F.C. and register it as a company. During this period the owners of the Hyde Road Hotel, Chesters Brewery, had a large influence over the football club, leading Ardwick to be nicknamed "The Brewerymen".<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p17</ref>
During the 1980s the Hyde Road Hotel was owned by [[George Heslop]], a former Manchester City player, and was renamed "The City Gates". The business failed, closing in 1989,<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', p355</ref> and the building subsequently lay empty for more than a decade. Attempts to save the building were made by Manchester City supporters, without much progress. By May 2001, the building was demolished.<ref>James, ''Manchester: The Greatest City'', pp18–19</ref> Two keystones from the Hyde Road Hotel reside in the memorial garden at the [[City of Manchester Stadium]].<ref>James, ''Manchester City – The Complete Record'', p24</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Use British English|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Ivor Preece Field | nickname = The 'Street | image = Overview shots of Street01.jpg | image_size = 300px | location = [[Binley Woods]], [[Warwickshire]], [[England]] | broke_ground = September 2000 | opened = August 2002 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Broadstreet Rugby Club]] | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = SR Davis Architects | former_names = | tenants = [[Broadstreet RUFC]] | capacity = 1,500 (250 seats) | dimensions = {{convert|46|acre|m2}} }} The '''Ivor Preece Field''' on Rugby Road, [[Binley Woods]], [[Warwickshire]] is the home ground of [[Broadstreet Rugby Club]], designed by SR Davis architects with the [[sports ground]] designed by Peter Jones Associates, [[Quantity surveyor|Quantity Surveyors]] Bucknall Austin, [[Project management|project managed]] by Falcon House Project Management.
The first game played here was on 1 March 2001 with the official opening in August 2002. The official opening day saw world cup winning captain [[Martin Johnson (rugby union)|Martin Johnson]] open the club and grounds. This saw a select presidents team take on the current first XV. The ground is named in honour of [[Ivor Preece]] (1920–87), who played for and captained [[Coventry R.F.C.]] and the [[England national rugby union team]] in the 1950s and was president of Broadstreet RUFC.
The {{convert|46|acre|m2}} allow up to five rugby matches and one football match to be played with two of the rugby pitches floodlit. The rugby club and facilities plays host to all manor of rugby sides on varying levels. Not only [[Broadstreet RUFC|Broadstreet RFC]] the grounds owners, but Coventry And District Union, Warwickshire RFU, Midlands RFU for training sessions and full games and [[English Premiership (rugby union)|Premiership]] side [[Wasps RFC|Wasps]] for training and [[Premiership Rugby A League]] matches. In early 2008 for England Deaf Rugby Union in their matches against The Welsh Deaf Rugby Union in February and March saw the visit of The Scottish Deaf Rugby Union XV.
The grounds have also played host to local football sides and the [[Coventry Cassidy Jets|Coventry Cassidy Jets American football team.]]
{{coord|52.3964|-1.4300|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}}

{{About|the men's team|the women's team|Kazakhstan women's national rugby union team}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2012}} {{Infobox rugby team | country = Kazakhstan | image= Kazakhstanrugbylogo.jpg | imagesize = | union = Kazakhstan Rugby Union | nickname = The Nomads | emblem = [[Steppe eagle]] | coach = Timur Mashurov | from = | captain = Serik Zhanseitov | caps = | top scorer = | countryflag = Kazakhstan | pattern_b1 = | pattern_ra1 = | leftarm1 = ffff00 | body1 = ffff00 | rightarm1 = ffff00 | shorts1 = 1E90FF | socks1 = ffff00 | pattern_la2 = | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = | leftarm2 = 1E90FF | body2 = 1E90FF | rightarm2 = 1E90FF | shorts2 = 000080 | socks2 = 1E90FF | first = {{ru-rt|Kazakhstan}} 5–17 {{ru|Georgia|1990}}
(4 March 1994) | bigwin = {{ru-rt|Kazakhstan}} 89–10 {{ru|India}}
(18 November 2002) | bigloss = {{ru-rt|Japan}} 101–7 {{ru|Kazakhstan}}
(15 May 2010) }} The '''Kazakhstan national rugby union team''', nicknamed "The Nomads", is controlled by the [[Kazakhstan Rugby Union]]. Kazakhstan have been participating in international competition since 1994 after their independence from the [[USSR]]. In 2007, the fortunes of the team greatly improved by winning all five of their matches and rising 14 places in the [[IRB World Rankings]] to 32nd. This rise was the biggest by any international team over the year. This led to the team being entered into the top division of the new [[Asian Five Nations]] in 2008.[http://www.irb.com/rankings/news/newsid=2021676.html International Rugby Board – 2007 rankings highs and lows]. 28 December 2007 Kazakhstan are now one of the leading rugby union nations in Asia, finishing second in the [[2009 Asian Five Nations|2009]] and [[2010 Asian Five Nations]] to continent heavyweights Japan on both occasions. Their second-place finish in 2010 saw them advance to the four-team playoff for a final place at the [[2011 Rugby World Cup]]. They lost 44–7 to [[Uruguay national rugby union team|Uruguay]] in Montevideo, being eliminated but it was still their best result yet. They have yet to qualify for a [[Rugby World Cup]] finals. ==Asian Five Nations Record== * [[2008 Asian Five Nations|2008]]: 4th * [[2009 Asian Five Nations|2009]]: 2nd * [[2010 Asian Five Nations|2010]]: 2nd * [[2011 Asian Five Nations|2011]]: 4th * [[2012 Asian Five Nations|2012]]: 5th ==Current squad== '''Squad to [[2011 Asian Five Nations]]:''' *Tairzhan Arzuev *Sergey Menshikov *Vladamir Chernhik *Serik Zhanseitov *Yevginey Shekurov *Nikolay Zhuravlev *Alexandr Zaharov *Timur Mashurov (c) *Akhmetzan Baratov *Daulet Akymbekov *Pavel Stikhin *Ildar Abdrazakov *Sergey Konev *Pavel Leonov *Vladamir Mitin '''Substitutes:''' *Vladamir Sitdikov *Dimitri Tkachenko *Anton Gunbin *Roman Sorokodyuba *Dimitri Tronin *Dastan Suleimenov *Evegeniy Romanov ==World Cup Record== {| border="1" cellpadding="2" !align="center" width="55px" | Year !align="center" width="120px" | Result !Reached |- |align="center"|1995 |align="left"|Did not Enter |N/A |- |align="center"|1999 |align="left"|Did not Enter |N/A |- |align="center"|2003 |align="left"|Did not Qualify |Asia Round 1 – Pool C (3rd) |- |align="center"|2007 |align="left"|Did not Qualify |Asia Round 1b Playoff |- |align="center"|2011 |align="left"|Did not Qualify |[[2011 Rugby World Cup Final Place Play-off|Final place play-offs]] |} ==See also== * [[Kazakhstan women's national rugby union team]] * [[Rugby union in Kazakhstan]] ==External links== * [http://kaz-rugby.kz/ Official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070310160757/http://impressions-ba.com/features.php?id_feature=10392 Tries and Tribulations] * [http://www.rugbyinternational.net/data/2010/2010-05/2010051501-jap-kaz.htm Current Squad] ==References== {{National rugby teams}} {{National sports teams of Kazakhstan}} [[Category:Kazakhstan national rugby union team| ]] [[Category:Asian national rugby union teams]] [[Category:Rugby union in Kazakhstan]] [[Category:National sports teams of Kazakhstan]] {{National-rugbyunion-team-stub}} {{Kazakhstan-sport-stub}}

'''Khyber Pakhtunkhwa cricket team''' is a Pakistani [[first-class cricket]] team.
As "North-West Frontier Province", the team competed in the [[Quaid-e-Azam Trophy]] sporadically from 1953-54 to 1978-79, and in the [[Pentangular Trophy|Pentangular Cup]] in 2007-08 and 2008–09, when it won the final. It has since played in the Pentangular Cup as Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.
The [[Pentangular Trophy]] team is a combined team of the best players from the Quaid-e-Azam Trophy who belong to [[Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]] province, selected from main domestic teams of the province such as [[Peshawar cricket team|Peshawar]] and [[Abbottabad cricket team|Abbottabad]].
==Current squad== * [[Mohammad Rizwan (cricketer, born 1992)|Mohammad Rizwan]] ([[captain (cricket)|c]], [[wicket-keeper|wk]]) * [[Shadab Khan]] * [[Iftikhar Ahmed (cricketer, born 1990)|Iftikhar Ahmed]] * [[Israrullah]] * [[Adil Amin]] * [[Imran Butt (cricketer)|Imran Butt]] * [[Mohammad Sami]] * [[Waqas Maqsood]] * [[Zafar Gohar]] * [[Shoaib Malik]] * [[Kashif Bhatti]] * [[Mohammad Naeem (cricketer, born 1990)|Mohammad Naeem]] * [[Taj Wali]] * [[Imran Khan (cricketer, born 1987)|Imran Khan]] * [[Nabi Gul]]
==External links== * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/0/254/First-Class_Matches.html First-class matches played by North West Frontier Province] * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Teams/14/14848/First-Class_Matches.html First-class matches played by Khyber Pakhtunkhwa]
